AvProblem.comment: gullies, steep bowls, behind discontinuities, near ridges
on steep grass-covered slopes, possible at any time of day or night, increasing with rain impact

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: Avalanche danger above 2300 m is moderate. Freshly generated snowdrift accumulations can be triggered by 1 person in some places, releases often medium-sized. Danger zones increase with ascending altitude, occur near steep ridgelines and in gullies and bowls. There is still latent danger of glide-snow avalanches, most releases medium-sized, occasionally larger. Due to solar radiation, loose-snow avalanches can be expected in extremely steep terrain in the afternoon, mostly small releases.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: Up to 2300 m the fresh snow is bonding well. Wherever wind transported the snow, weak layers can form inside the drifts. Above 2400 m the surface hoar is being covered. On W/N/E facing slopes at high altitudes there are faceted layers near superficial melt-freeze crusts. The snow from Wednesday is sticky up to 2000 m, above it dry at least on shady slopes.
BulletinMeasurements.wxSynopsisComment: During the night the snowfall will taper off, snowfall level will drop to 600-800 m by morning. All in all, max. 5-10 cm of fresh snow. Winds northerly mostly light-to-moderate, gusts of 50 km/hr in Hohe Tauern. Thursday will start heavily overcast, frequent snow showers in the morning, but minor amounts. In the afternoon, clouds will start to disperse, visibility improve, winds light-to-moderate from the north. At 2000 m: -6 degrees; at 3000 m: -12 degrees.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Avalanche danger levels are not expected to change significantly.

AvProblem.comment: in steep grass-covered terrain, possible at any time of day or night

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: Avalanche danger is low. Small snowdrift accumulations can be triggered by 1 person in a few danger zones, releases mostly small. There is latent danger of glide-snow avalanches, sometimes reaching medium size. Small snowdrift accumulations can be triggered in places by minimum additional loading, releases mostly small. Due to solar radiation in the afternoon, small loose-snow avalanches possible in extremely steep terrain.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The shallow fresh snow was deposited atop an irregular, mostly hard snowpack surface, is bonding well. At low and intermediate altitudes the snowpack is often thoroughly moist.
BulletinMeasurements.wxSynopsisComment: During the night the snowfall will taper off, snowfall level will drop to 600-800 m by morning. All in all, max. 5-10 cm of fresh snow. Winds northerly mostly light-to-moderate.Â Thursday will start heavily overcast, frequent snow showers in the morning, but minor amounts. In the afternoon, clouds will start to disperse, visibility improve, winds light-to-moderate from the north. At 2000 m: -6 degrees.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Avalanche danger levels are not expected to change significantly.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: Avalanche danger is LOW. On extremely steep grass-covered slopes isolated small glide-snow avalanches are possible, but seldom.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The is generally compact and stable, is often moist up to high altitudes, wet at ground level. In all aspects there is a melt-freeze crust, capable of bearing loads on south-facing slopes, on north-facing slopes breakable crusts can be expected.
BulletinMeasurements.wxSynopsisComment: During the night the snowfall will taper off, snowfall level will drop to 600-800 m by morning. All in all, max. 5-10 cm of fresh snow. Winds northerly mostly light-to-moderate. Thursday will start heavily overcast, frequent snow showers in the morning, but minor amounts. In the afternoon, clouds will start to disperse, visibility improve, winds light-to-moderate from the north. At 2000 m: -6 degrees; at 3000 m: -12 degrees.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Avalanche danger levels are not expected to change significantly.
